description.narrative: The expected project-level outcomes are the offloading of NPLs by banks and normalization of the financial position of defaulted debtors who are currently unable to access formal credit. The sale of NPL portfolios will help banks meet their NPL reduction targets and reduce associated funding and administrative costs, and thereby improving their profitability and capital position over time, which in turn may strengthen their capacity to lend. Beyond the Project, IFC anticipates that the investment, via demonstration and replication channels, will increase market competitiveness and integration and likely to have a catalytic effect in the unsecured retail NPL space in the region's distressed asset market. In terms of competitiveness, the Project is expected to contribute toward the entry of new servicers specialized in unsecured retail NPLs into Southeast Asia and the market-wide adoption of best practices by servicers active in resolving unsecured retail NPLs. The Project will contribute toward market integration by triggering the mobilization of foreign capital into Southeast Asian NPL markets as the platform will serve as a model for other investors to replicate as they consider investing in the region.

The project is part of IFCs Distressed Asset Recovery Program (DARP) and proposes an investment of up to US$30 million through a combination of senior and junior loans to a DARP platform (DARP SPV CCM) being set up by Collectius AG (Collectius or the Company). Collectius will also provide similar US$30 million funding to the SPV. The proceeds will be used to acquire and resolve unsecured retail non-performing loans (NPLs) in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam (Target Markets), allowing Collectius to expand in these markets. Additionally, IFC is also evaluating a minority equity investment in Collectius to bolster a strong partnership aimed at building unsecured retail NPL resolution capacity across Asia.
